sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is designed to help you monitor the system log files for messages that interest you, alerting you when interesting events occur. You can define filters to control which messages are displayed on screen, and which ones display alerts.

The system log files are written by a syslog server (available in all Linux distributions and UNIX variants). Syslog can be configured to forward messages to other computers; by configuring syslog appropriately you can monitor multiple computers from a single instance of &app;.

sect2.title: Configuring Syslog
sect2.para: Before running &app; for the first time you will need to create a named pipe (otherwise known as a FIFO) for it to monitor. The default path is ~/.bandsaw.fifo, but you may change it to anything you wish. To make the named pipe, type the following command at the command line, then press Return:

Once you have made the FIFO you will need to configure your syslog server accordingly. The configuration commands vary between different servers (and you should refer to your server's documentation for full details), but here is an example for sysklogd. It specifies that all messages of priority notice and higher should be written to &app;'s FIFO.
Much more complicated configurations are possible, and it can pay to become familiar with the server's configuration file.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: The first time you start &app; you will be asked to specify the location to the named pipe that you have configured syslog to write to (see ). You may either accept the default (~/.bandsaw.fifo) or specify a different path entirely.

note.para: If the path that you specify does not exist, or is not readable by your user account, you will not be able to proceed until you have corrected the problem.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, and log message view.

sect2.para: The main area of the &app; window is used to display all the log messages that match any of the filters that you define. New messages are added to the bottom of the view as they arrive from syslog. If the maximum number of messages is exceeded then the old messages will be automatically removed from the top of the view.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para:
For each log message that is received from syslog, &app; checks whether or not it should:
Ignore the message
Show the message in the message view
Show the message in the message view and display an alert dialog
By default all messages will just be shown in the main window, but you may control the behaviour by configuring your own filters.

sect2.title: Managing the Message View
sect2.para: Log messages are added to the message view as they arrive from syslog.

listitem.para:
To remove all the messages from the message view, choose
Edit Clear .

You may also remove individual messages by selecting them with the mouse or cursor keys and choosing
Delete
Edit Delete Selected .

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window, with Edit menu selected for removing messages from the view.

tip.para:
You can quickly select a continous group of messages by left clicking on the first message in the group, scrolling down, holding down the Shift key and left clicking on the last message in the group.
You may also navigate and select messages with the Home, End and cursor keys, in combination with the Shift key.

sect2.title: Alert Dialogs
sect2.para: When an incoming message matches a filter that has been configured to raise alerts &app; will display an alert dialog.

textobject.phrase: Shows a &app; alert dialog, including the log message text, the host where the messages was generated, and options to ignore forthcoming alerts.

listitem.para:
The name of the filter that matched the message
— "Error" in this example.

The name of the host that created the message
— "hoopoo" in this example.

The text of the log message
— "ERROR: Something has gone wrong!" above.

sect2.para: Click the OK button to dismiss the alert.

The dialog also provides the option to Ignore alerts for a configurable number of minutes. This feature allows you to resolve problems uninterrupted if you are unfortunate enough to be receiving a continuous stream of log messages!

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, choose
Edit Preferences . The Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: Use this setting to modify the path to the named pipe (or FIFO) that is being written to by your syslog server. The FIFO must exist, and be accessible by the user account that is running &app;.
Use this spin button to control the maximum number of log messages that can be kept in the message view. The larger the number the greater the resources required.

sect2.title: Filters
sect2.para: You can set the following viewer preferences:

sect3.title: Image Windows
sect3.para: The Image Windows group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in image windows.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the image window.
Default: Never.

term.guilabel: Pick window size and zoom factor automatically

listitem.para: Select this option to resize the image window to fit the image or to resize the image to fit the image window. If the image is small, &app; resizes the image window to fit the image. If the image is large, &app; resizes the image to fit the image window.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Open images in a new window

listitem.para: Select this option to open a new &app; window each time you open an image. If you do not select this option, &app; replaces the existing image with the new image when you open an image.
Default: unselected.

sect3.title: Full Screen
sect3.para: The Full Screen group contains the preferences that you can set to view images in full screen mode.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify when to use scrollbars to scroll through an image. Select one of the following options:
This option never displays scrollbars. You can use the arrow keys on the keyboard or the mouse to scroll through the image.

para.guilabel: Only if image does not fit

listitem.para: This option displays scrollbars when the image is larger than the full screen.
Default: Never.
Select this option to use the 1:1 zoom factor when you open an image. The 1:1 zoom factor displays the image at its actual size.
Default: selected.

term.guilabel: Use same zoom factor as image window

listitem.para: Select this option to use the same zoom factor that the application uses to display the image in an image window.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to resize images to fill the full screen when you open the images in full screen mode.
Default: unselected.

Select this option to automatically resize images that are the same size as standard screens so that the images fill the full screen when you open them in full screen mode. If you select this option, &app; ignores the settings for the previous three options when you open an image that is the same size as a standard screen. Examples of standard screen sizes are 640 x 480 pixels, 1024 x 768 pixels, and so on.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Put a bevel around the edge of the screen

listitem.para: Select this option to display a 3D beveled border around the full screen view of an image.
Default: unselected.
